item.title: Creating a bootable USB
item.description: Beware of your UEFI/Secure Boot settings while preparing the USB and installing the distro. If you have UEFI enabled, use the GPT option in Rufus and UNetbootin. If you’re running CSM/Legacy mode or don’t have UEFI on your laptop, use the MBR option. In most cases, using the GPT/UEFI option should work just fine with newer laptops. You’ll need an USB stick with at least 2 GB of space.

item.title: Installation
item.description: The official Ubuntu installation guide can be found here. (Steps below adapted from the official tut.) After booting from the USB, you’ll see the window below. 1. Select your language from the left and select the Install Ubuntu option. Depending on your computer’s configuration, you may instead see an alternative boot menu showing a large language selection pane (see below). Just select the Install Ubuntu option, and you’ll see the welcome window above in no-time.
